topic.title: Deploying VSA with Virtual Control Plane

abstract.shortdesc: supports deployment of control plane elements on the virtual machines which can be co-located on the one baremetal machine or spread across the three baremetal machines.

body.p: supports deployment of control plane elements on the virtual machines which can be co-located on the one baremetal machine or spread across the three baremetal machines. The baremetal machine in this context are termed as VM factory host(s). VSA can be deployed on the VM factory host.

The following section illustrates the change in the input model for X1 and S1 model ONLY. The change in the input model for M1 model is similar except that VSA is deployed as the resource nodes. For other aspects of cluster management like upgrade, adding new set of disks, stopping and starting services and so on, you can follow the similar approach that is used for the deployment of ceph cluster using .

The HPE StoreVirtual Centralized Management Console (CMC) GUI is an interface where you can configure VSA. The following choices are available for deploying CMC with virtual control plane:
Deploy CMC on single VM factor host. You can access CMC by connecting to VM factory host.
Deploy CMC on single Controller. You can access CMC by connectiong to controller node.
body.section:
Steps to deploy VSA on a VM factory host
Log in to the lifecycle manager.
Go to ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/.Assumptions is that you have already copied cloud model representing contorl element depeloyment on VM factory host(s).
Edit your contorl plane (typically referenced in control_plane.yml) to add VSA components to vmfactory nodes. For example: - name: vmfactory resource-prefix: vmf server-role: HLM-HYPERVISOR-ROLE min-count: allocation-policy: strict service-components: - ntp-server - vsa - lifecycle-manager - tempest - openstack-client
Edit your contorl plane (typically referenced in control_plane.yml) to add CMC component: For CMC to be deployed on VMfactory node, add cmc in vmfactory service-components. For example: - name: vmfactory resource-prefix: vmf server-role: HLM-HYPERVISOR-ROLE min-count: allocation-policy: strict service-components: - ntp-server - vsa - cmc-service - lifecycle-manager - tempest - openstack-client
For CMC be deployed on Controller node, add cmc in controller service-components. For example: - name: cluster1 cluster-prefix: c1 server-role: CONTROLLER-ROLE member-count: 1 allocation-policy: strict service-components: - ntp-server - cmc-service
Edit disks_vmfactory.yml file of VM factory hosts to define disks for VSA. For e.g. the below disk model illustrates usage of /dev/sdd for adaptive optimization, /dev/sde and /dev/sdf as data disks. --- product: version: 2
disk-models: - name: HLM-HYPERVISOR-DISKS volume-groups: - name: hlm-vg physical-volumes: - /dev/sda_root logical-volumes: # The policy is not to consume 100% of the space of each volume group. # 5% should be left free for snapshots and to allow for some flexibility. - name: root size: 35% fstype: ext4 mount: / - name: log size: 50% mount: /var/log fstype: ext4 mkfs-opts: -O large_file - name: crash size: 10% mount: /var/crash fstype: ext4 mkfs-opts: -O large_file - name: vg-images # this VG is dedicated to libvirt images to keep VM IOPS off the OS disk 45 physical-volumes: - /dev/sdb - /dev/sdc logical-volumes: - name: images size: 95% mount: /var/lib/libvirt/images fstype: ext4 mkfs-opts: -O large_file
device-groups: - name: vsa-data consumer: name: vsa usage: data devices: - name: /dev/sde - name: /dev/sdf - name: vsa-cache consumer: name: vsa usage: adaptive-optimization devices: - name: /dev/sdd
Commit your configuration to the local git repocd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"
After setting up the configuration files, continue with the installation procedures mentioned at .
